The chapter on defiling families, the nineteenth chapter on defiling families, at that time the Blessed One was in the city of ÅšrÄvastÄ«.
At that time there were twelve bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«s on Mount Isigili:ğŸ”½Nanda, Upananda, ÅšuklÄnanda, Ratna-cÅ«á¸Ä,
Pá¹›thivÄ«, Pá¹›thivÄ«-varÄ, VarÄ-pá¹›thivÄ«, VarÄ-pá¹›thivÄ«, RevatÄ«,
BhadrÄ, SubhadrÄ, and SundarÄ«. All of them
were defiling families with evil practices. They played and laughed with men, exchanged pleasantries,
and engaged in frivolous activities. They touched each other's bodies, sat on the same bed, ate from the same dish, and drank from the same cup.
They picked flowers and fruits as they pleased, sang and danced, and adorned their bodies with cosmetics.
They were heedless, agitated, lying on their backs, rolling around, like fish flopping, or neighing like horses, or
lowing like cows, making all sorts of sounds in their mouths, birds and sparrows fighting, and men and women
grabbing each other, playing like this, doing all sorts of improper things.

Because of this, the bad reputation of the village on Mount KÄ«á¹­Ä spread, and all the nuns who wanted to come here, hearing this foul noise, did not come again, and the old residents all scattered in all directions.

At that time, many bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«s were traveling here. In the early morning, they took their robes and bowls and entered the village to beg for food, but returned with empty bowls, having obtained nothing.
The bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«s then thought:
This great village is prosperous, peaceful, and abundant. All beggars can fill their bellies. Why is it that we have obtained nothing?

Could it be that the nuns first stayed here and did many unwholesome things, engaging in defiling activities, doing improper things, physically touching each other, and thus causing people to lose faith?

At that time, the elders in the village were discussing together in one place. Among them was a lay disciple named UrÅ«ka. He saw the begging nuns enter with empty bowls and return with empty bowls. Having seen this, he stood to one side and asked the nuns,
Why do you return empty-handed?
The nuns then explained the matter in detail.
The lay disciple said,
In that case, you may go to the city of ÅšrÄvastÄ«. You should inform the World-Honored One of this matter. Out of compassion for us,
The bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«s silently accepted his words. At that time, the lay disciple bowed at the feet of the nuns and said,
Noble ones!
Today, out of compassion for me, please accept a small offering in my house.
The nuns accepted it.

Having arrived at the house, she personally offered them delicious food until they were all full, chewed tooth wood, washed, put away the bowls, and the patron took a seat in front to listen to the nuns speak the Dharma, giving them instruction, benefit, and joy, and then left.
Then the group of nuns traveled through the country of Kosala, gradually arriving at ÅšrÄvastÄ«.
When the nuns there saw the visiting nuns, they immediately relieved their fatigue and exchanged greetings, saying:
Have you been at ease?
The nuns reported the matter in detail.
When the nuns heard this, they told the monks, and the monks informed the Buddha.
The Buddha said to MahÄprajÄpatÄ«:
GautamÄ«!
Can you, together with five hundred senior nuns, go to Mount Isigili to perform the act of banishing for the twelve nuns?
She replied:
Venerable!
I am indeed able to go.
The Buddha said:
GautamÄ«!
There are five causes and conditions for performing the act of banishment that are contrary to the Dharma and the Vinaya, and the nuns' assembly commits a transgression of the precepts.
What are the five?
Namely, first, not questioning;
second, not causing them to recollect;
third, not investigating the matter;
fourth, they do not confess themselves;
fifth, the person is not present.

Although they have actually committed an offense, they should be made to repent by being questioned about it. Having confessed, they should not be made to confess again. These are called the five kinds of unlawful banishment, and the assembly commits a transgression of the precepts.
There are also five conditions for performing the act of banishment:
In accordance with the Dharma, in accordance with the Vinaya, the assembly does not commit a transgression of the precepts, the opposite of the above should be known.
If you wish to go to that mountain, you may stay at a place on the way, and you should appoint a nun to question the nuns.
If they do not have the five dharmas, they should not be appointed, and if appointed, they should be dismissed.
What are the five?
Having affection, hatred, fear, delusion, and not being able to understand what is questioned and what is not questioned.
If there are five qualities that are the opposite of those, one should not dismiss them.
What are the five?
The opposite of the above should be known.
One should be appointed like this.
As usual, having assembled the saá¹…gha, one should first ask them:

If the bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä« saá¹…gha thinks it is the right time and agrees, the saá¹…gha should allow the saá¹…gha to now appoint bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä« So-and-so as the questioner to go to Mount á¹šá¹£i to question the twelve bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«s who have defiled the householders.
The motion is as follows.'
The karman should be performed according to the motion.
Next, you should go to the city of KÄ«á¹­Ägiri, set out seats, and ring the ghanta.
If they come when they hear the sound, it is good. If they do not come, you should perform the karma of banishing them.
If they come, you should inform them of the original matter:

When the twelve heard that MahÄprajÄpatÄ« wanted to perform the karma of banishing them, at that time BhadrÄ, SubhadrÄ, SundarÄ«, and Åšreá¹£á¹­hin thought like this:

Then she took her robes and bowl and left the city through the western gate, gradually traveling to ÅšrÄvastÄ«. The offenses that could be confessed were confessed according to the rules, and those that required remorse were atoned for according to the rules. She used the same things as the pure nuns.

The great MahÄprajÄpatÄ« with five hundred people entered through the eastern gate of the city and went to their dwelling place. They set out seats and rang the ghanta. The other twelve heard and all came to assemble.
The questioning nun asked the twelve:

If the community of bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«s agrees to the time, the community of bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«s should approve. The bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«s NandÄ and others, having committed acts that defile the householders, are not abandoning their actions. The community now performs the karman of banishing them.

Then the upÄsaka UrubilvÄ said to MahÄprajÄpatÄ«:

Then the upÄsaka UrÅ«bila, having seen them accept, prepared food and drink that very night. The next day at dawn, he sent a messenger to invite them:

Then MahÄprajÄpatÄ« GautamÄ«, wandering among the people, reached ÅšrÄvastÄ«. She put away her robes and bowl, washed her feet, and went to the Buddha. She bowed her head at the Buddha's feet, stood to one side, and said to the Buddha:

Then the nuns NandÄ and UpanandÄ said to each other:

If a person falls to the ground, they rely on the ground to get up. Let us go together to ÅšrÄvastÄ« and seek forgiveness and repent before the Buddha, the nun MahÄprajÄpatÄ«, and the assembly of nuns.

The Buddha said:
When you see them, you should not speak to them. If there are elder nuns, do not pay homage to them. If younger nuns come to pay homage, do not say:
'Are you well?'
If they seek lodging, give them a room on the edge. If they seek bedding and necessities, give them old and broken things.

At that time, MahÄprajÄpatÄ« GautamÄ«, having heard the Buddha's words, paid homage to the Buddha and left.
At that time, AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada went to where the World-Honored One was, bowed his head at the Buddha's feet, and sat to one side. Joining his palms, he said:

I have heard that the nuns NandÄ and UpanandÄ have come to this city and are engaging in defiled and evil practices. What should I do now?
The Buddha said:

Then the nuns NandÄ and UpanandÄ went to MahÄprajÄpatÄ« and the other elder nuns, bowed their heads in greeting, but the elder nuns did not reply with wishes for their good health and happiness.
The younger nuns did not pay respect, and when they asked for bedding they got old and worn-out things, and when they sought a place to stay they got the worst rooms. They then said:

At that time MahÄprajÄpatÄ« skillfully told them:

Then the nuns NandÄ and UpanandÄ and the others discussed like this:
The words and intentions of what we have done, those BhadrÄ, SundarÄ«, and Åšreá¹£á¹­hi and the others, are similar to us, the matter is no different.

When they arrived there, at that time Bhadda and the others saw the nun coming, but none of them spoke to her joyfully or greeted her.
When she saw this, she said:
It is reasonable that the elder nuns would not speak to me, but you, who previously had similar behavior and speech to me, why do you also not see fit to welcome me?
The nuns replied:

Our behavior and speech were indeed not different before, but we have already confessed our offenses that should be confessed, and we have already repented our offenses that should be repented. We are pure and without offense, and therefore we cannot share with you, a person of evil conduct and broken precepts, as we do with those who uphold the precepts.
Having heard this, she said:

... up to ... the act of ejecting them through the proclamation of a fourth (act of) information.
(The nuns) stubbornly held on to (their views) and refused to let go, saying:

The Buddha, on this account, assembled the nuns as before, questioned them about the facts, reprimanded them, and... established the training rule, which should be recited like this:
If there is a nun who, living in a village or town, corrupts families and engages in bad behavior, and the corruption of families and bad behavior are seen and heard by many people,
the other nuns should tell that nun:
'Venerable!

You have defiled the families and engaged in misconduct. The families have been defiled and this is seen, heard, and known by many, and you have engaged in misconduct and this is also seen, heard, and known by many.
You should leave and should not stay here.'
Those bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«s said to the bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«s:

You should abandon attachment, anger, and so forth.
If the bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«s admonish in this way and the other abandons [the practice], it is good.
If she does not abandon it, she should be admonished up to three times. She should be questioned according to the rule and admonished.

Bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä« refers to Nanda, Upananda, and so forth, or any other bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«, up to three or more people.

Corrupting a family means corrupting a family for two reasons.
What are the two?
First, living together; second, enjoying together.
What is meant by living together?
It means sitting on the same bed as a man, eating from the same dish, drinking from the same cup, and amusing oneself with laughter.
What is meant by enjoying together?
It means using tree leaves, flowers, fruits, toothbrushes, and so forth.
One who practices evil conduct refers to one who practices coarse and heavy sinful and evil dharmas.

If the bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«s admonish her separately and she abandons [her view], it is good;
if she does not abandon it, she commits a sthÅ«lÄtyaya offense.
The rest is explained in the same way as in the section on breaking the saá¹ƒgha.
20. The training rule on being difficult to correct together with the Buddha.

She stubbornly refused to let go, saying:

In this way, the TathÄgata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened One's assembly of Å›rÄvakas will then increase and mutually admonish.

You should abandon this matter.

if she does not abandon it, it is a saá¹ƒghÄvaÅ›eá¹£a offense.

The bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«s refers to the nuns in this Dharma.

In the Buddha's spoken PrÄtimoká¹£a sÅ«tras means that the Buddha, the Great Teacher, spoke the eight pÄrÄjika offenses, twenty saá¹ƒghÄvaÅ›eá¹£a offenses, thirty-three niá¸¥sargikÄpatti-pÄyantika offenses, one hundred and eighty pÄyantika offenses, eleven pratideÅ›anÄ«ya offenses, many Å›aiká¹£a rules, and seven methods for resolving disputes in the PrÄtimoká¹£a sÅ«tras.

Up to three admonishments, explained in detail as before.
What are the rules for committing offenses in this case?

Venerable ones!
I have already explained the twenty saá¹ƒghÄvaÅ›eá¹£a offenses, twelve of which are first offenses and eight require up to three admonishments.

Now I ask the Venerable Ones:

The first summary verse of the nuns' two undetermined offenses:
Keeping, storing, washing clothes, taking clothes, begging, and excessive receiving,
The same price and different owners, sending a messenger to deliver the robe money.
The training rule on not determining a long robe, the first training rule on not determining a long robe. The circumstances were in ÅšrÄvastÄ«.

At that time the monks had many long robes. Every time they chewed on a tooth stick, washed their hands and feet, paid respect to the two teachers, paid respect to the World-Honored One, swept the temple grounds, or applied cow dung, or went into the village to beg for food, or ate food, received teachings and listened to the Dharma, at these times they put on different robes, stretched out and folded them, and had many affairs, neglecting to cultivate wholesome activities, recitation and contemplation.
At that time the monks who had few desires saw this and criticized it together:
How can the monks hoard many long robes and neglect to cultivate the correct practices?
The monks reported the matter to the Buddha.
The Buddha assembled the two assemblies and explained in detail as before. After asking and knowing the truth, he reprimanded them in various ways:
Those with much desire are difficult to satisfy and difficult to fill.
Praising those who have few desires, are content, easy to support, easy to satisfy, and know moderation in receiving, and cultivating the practice of reducing desires, he told the bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«s:
Explained in detail up to I see ten benefits, for the disciples of the two schools I establish the precepts, which should be said like this:
If a bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«, after finishing making robes, and the kaá¹­hina frame has been taken down, obtains extra cloth, she should distribute it.

At that time, after the World Honored One had established the precepts for the disciples who listen to him, there was an elder who gave cloth, as in the Vinaya for bhiká¹£us, up to The previous was newly established, and now it is further permitted, which should be said like this:

Having finished making robes, the kaá¹­hina has also been removed means there are cases where one has finished making robes but the kaá¹­hina has not been removed, there are cases where the kaá¹­hina has been removed but one has not finished making robes, there are cases where one has finished making robes and the kaá¹­hina has also been removed, and there are cases where one has not finished making robes and the kaá¹­hina has not been removed.

The fourth case is if a bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä« has not finished making robes, and the kaá¹­hina has not been removed.
Obtaining an extra robe for ten days refers to ten nights.
Long robe means having a robe other than the one being kept, one should keep it with the method of distinguishing it.
If one keeps it beyond that, it is nisaggiya pÄcittiya means this item should be relinquished and the offense confessed.
PÄcittiya means the meaning of burning, cooking, and falling.
It means that if one commits an offense, one falls into the evil destinies of hell, animals, and hungry ghosts, and experiences the suffering of being burned and cooked.
Moreover, if one commits this offense and does not earnestly confess it, it can obstruct all wholesome dharmas, and therefore it is called pÄcittiya.

What are the characteristics of committing this offense?ğŸ”½If a bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä« obtains a robe on the first day of the month, within ten days she should keep it, relinquish it, make it into a robe, or give it to others.
If she does not keep it, relinquish it, make it into a robe, or give it to others, and the morning of the eleventh day dawns, it is nisaggiya pÄcittiya.

If a bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä« obtains robes on one day and does not obtain robes on the second day, up to obtaining robes on the tenth day, and does not keep them, etc., when the morning of the eleventh day arrives, the robes obtained during the nine days are all offenses entailing relinquishment and confession.
In this way, up to the robes obtained on the eighth day, etc., the number of days and robes should be known according to the previous method.

If a bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä« obtains robes on one day and obtains robes on the second day, that bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä« should keep the robes obtained earlier and relinquish the robes obtained later within ten days, or the opposite.
If she does not perform the rite, when the morning of the eleventh day arrives, the robes obtained during the two days are all offenses entailing relinquishment and confession.
In this way, up to the robes obtained on the third day, etc., the matter should be known according to the circumstances.
If a bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä« obtains five robes on one day, up to obtaining robes on the second day, etc., she should perform the rite in the same way as before.
If one does not perform the rite, when the light of the eleventh day appears, all [the extra robes] become subject to the niá¸¥sargika-pÄtayantikÄ offense.
If a bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä« obtains many robes on one day, whether before or after, she should keep one robe and make a rite for the rest.
If she does not perform the rite, when the light of the eleventh day appears, all [the extra robes] become subject to the niá¸¥sargika-pÄtayantikÄ offense.
If a bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä« obtains many robes on one day and obtains many robes on the second day and so on, the rite is the same as before.

If she does not perform the rite, when the light of the eleventh day appears, the offense is the same as before. All of these are due to the fault of the previous [robe] contaminating the subsequent [robes] and causing them to arise in continuity.

If a bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä« commits a niá¸¥sargika-pÄtayantikÄ offense regarding a robe, if she does not relinquish that robe, does not spend a night [with it], and does not confess that offense, if she obtains another robe, all [the robes] become subject to the niá¸¥sargika-pÄtayantikÄ offense.
If a bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«'s niá¸¥sargikÄ robe is relinquished but not spent the night, and the offense is not confessed, the other robes she obtains are all subject to relinquishment.
If she relinquishes the robe and spends the night but does not confess the offense, the other robes she obtains are all subject to relinquishment, due to the previous defilement.
If a bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä« keeps an extra robe and commits a pÄrÄjika offense, it is not for the three matters.

Whatever robes she obtains, or alms bowl, bowl bag, water strainer, waist belt, and so forth, up to whatever she obtains as a Å›ramaá¹‡Ä«'s requisites for maintaining life, are all niá¸¥sargikÄ pÄyantika, due to the previous defilement.
If she relinquishes the robe, spends the night, confesses the offense, and obtains other robes, they are all without offense.
The training rule on being apart from the five robes, the second training rule on being apart from the five robes, the same place as before.

At that time, the bhiká¹£us had many of the three robes. The cloth they obtained during the retreat, after washing, dyeing, and sewing, they put in cloth bags, tied them securely, and entrusted them to the host bhiká¹£us. They put on the upper and lower robes and traveled among the people.
After they left, the host bhiká¹£us stored them, dried them in the sun, and spread them out. There was much work to do, and they neglected recitation, meditation, and contemplation.
The bhiká¹£us who were frugal became disgusted and said:
How can a bhiká¹£u keep many extra robes, interfering with others' right practice?
Then the bhiká¹£us reported this matter to the Buddha.

The Buddha, for this cause, assembled the Saá¹ƒgha as before, questioned them about the facts, and reprimanded them. He then explained in detail up to establishing the training rule, which should be recited like this:

If a bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«, after finishing making her robes, when the kaá¹­hina frame has been dismantled, separates from any one of the five robes and stays outside the monastic boundary for even one night, it is an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.

In this way, the World-Honored One having established a training rule for the disciples, at that time MahÄkÄÅ›yapa's robe was heavy, like the bhiká¹£u vinaya, and so on, the previous was newly established, now further relaxed, should be said like this:

If a bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«, having finished making the robe, and the kaá¹­hina frame has been taken down, separates from any one of the five robes, and stays outside the boundary for at least one night, except for the assembly's ritual, it is a nissaggiya pÄcittiya offense.
Having finished making the robe, and the kaá¹­hina frame has been taken down, there are four sentences of distinction, like the previous.

As for separating from any one of the robes, among the five robes of saá¹ƒghÄá¹­Ä«, uttarÄsaá¹…ga, antarvÄsa, kaupÄ«na, and niá¹£Ä«dana, if one separates from any one robe and stays in a different boundary until dawn, except for the saá¹ƒgha's ritual, it is a nissaggiya pÄcittiya offense.
This offense of relinquishing the item is the same as before, with the ritual.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
What are the circumstances of the offenses in this section?
The summary verse says:
One house, two houses, many houses, villages, surrounded by walls, fences, or moats,
Households, non-Buddhist houses, shops, buildings, and fields,
Halls, carts, boats, forests, and trees, all have four different situations,
In the four dignified deportments, one should be well aware of those robes.
There are villages with one house, two houses, and many houses;
Villages surrounded by walls, villages surrounded by fences, and villages surrounded by moats.
One village has one sphere of influence and many spheres of influence;
Many villages have one sphere of influence and many spheres of influence;
One household has one sphere of influence and many spheres of influence;
Many households have one sphere of influence and many spheres of influence, this is how it should be understood.

If it is a house of entertainers, a house of non-Buddhists, a shop, a building, a field, a hall, a cart, a boat, a forest, or a tree, they all have four different situations of one or many spheres of influence.
What is a single house village?
It refers to a mountain village where people live in a single house.
What is the extent of its influence?
It refers to the entire house, both inside and outside, with a perimeter of one fathom.
Moreover, it also refers to the places where rice is threshed, roasted, ground, eaten, and where people gather, which are also considered its influence.
If a bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«'s robe is in the house while her body is within the influence, or if her robe is within the influence while her body is in the house, when dawn breaks there is no offense.
If she leaves her robe in the house or within the influence, while her body is in a different place, she incurs the offense of pÄrÄjika.
If it is like this for a single house, it is the same for two houses.
What is a many-house village?
It refers to a village where the houses are scattered, with no fixed order.
What is the extent of its influence?
Is it different?
Is it the same?
The answer is:
This village has no influence and no common area.
The boundary for leaving the robe is based on the individual houses.
What is a village surrounded by walls?
It refers to a village surrounded by walls on all four sides.
What is the extent of its influence?
It refers to within the walls, extending one fathom outside, and also to the distance a chicken can fly, and also to the distance a person with shame can defecate - this is its influence.
The rest is explained as before.
What is a village surrounded by fences?
It refers to a village surrounded by fences on all four sides.
What is the extent of its influence?

It refers to within the fences, extending one fathom outside, and also to the distance cattle and sheep can reach with their feet, and also to the distance six oxen can turn a bamboo cart - this is its influence.
What is a village surrounded by moats?
It refers to a village surrounded by moats on all four sides.
What is the extent of its influence?

It refers to the area within the moat, extending one fathom outward, and also the area reached by a ladder twelve cubits long, and also the area reached by large bricks and stones when throwing out garbage, which is its sphere of influence.
What is meant by one village having one sphere of influence?
It refers to a village where there is one garden, one temple, or one gathering place. This is called one village having one sphere of influence.
What is the extent of this sphere of influence?

It refers to the area outside the garden, extending one fathom, and also the area reached by pounding, threshing, roasting, grinding, eating, and gathering for meals, which is its sphere of influence.
What is meant by one village having many spheres of influence?
It refers to a village where there are many gardens, many temples, or many gathering places. This is called one village having many spheres of influence.
What is the extent of these spheres of influence?ğŸ”½Are they different?
Or are they the same?
Answer:
This has no sphere of influence, but is limited to within the room.
How does a group of many villages have one sphere of influence?
It means that in this group of many villages there is one garden, one temple, or one place where the assembly gathers. This is called a group of many villages having one sphere of influence.
What is the extent of this sphere of influence?

It is all within the village, and each one arrow-shot outside. Moreover, it is also the place where pounding, threshing, roasting, grinding, eating, and drinking gather, which is also called the sphere of influence.
How does a group of many villages have many spheres of influence?

It means that in this group of many villages there are many gardens, many temples, and many places where the assembly gathers. This is called a group of many villages having many spheres of influence.
What is the extent of this sphere of influence?ğŸ”½Is it different?
Or is it the same?
Answer:
This has no sphere of influence, and the rest is the same as before.
How does a single household have one sphere of influence?

It means that in this household there is only one head of the household, brothers and sisters. This is called a single household having one sphere of influence, and the matter is the same as the previous explanation of a single house or village.
How does one household have multiple spheres of influence?
It means that within this household there are multiple household heads, etc., distinctions. This is called one household having multiple spheres of influence.
What is the extent of this called a sphere of influence?
It means up to the gate, beyond which there is no sphere of influence.
How does many households have one sphere of influence?
It means that among the various households there is only one household head, with brothers not divided. This is called many households having one sphere of influence.
How does many households have multiple spheres of influence?
It means that within these various households there are multiple household heads, with distinctions between brothers.
What is the extent of this called a sphere of influence?
This has no sphere of influence, the rest is the same as before.
How does one musical household have one sphere of influence?
The entire house, with one fathom outside.
Moreover, up to the placement of poles, drums, pipa, flutes, the preparation of offerings, and the gathering for food and drink, this is also a sphere of influence.
How does one musical household have multiple spheres of influence?
It means that in this household there are many heads of households, with brothers divided into separate households. This is called one household with multiple spheres of influence.
What is the extent of these spheres of influence?
What is common?
What is separate?
Separate refers to the boundaries of the residences of those brothers. Common refers to the area up to the placement of flags and poles.
How does a household with many musicians have one sphere of influence?
It means that in these households there is only one head of household, with brothers not divided into separate households. This is called many households with one sphere of influence.
What is the extent of this sphere of influence?
The entire house, with an area of one fathom outside, and also up to the placement of poles and so forth, are all considered the sphere of influence.
How does a household with many musicians have multiple spheres of influence?
It means that in these households there are many heads of households, with brothers divided into separate households.
What is the extent of these spheres of influence?
What is common?
What is separate?
The answer is:
This has no sphere of influence.
How does a single non-Buddhist household have one sphere of influence?

It means that in this household they have the same views and do not have different intentions. This influence extends throughout the house and one fathom outside, and also includes the places for drying cow dung, storing firewood, leather garments, bamboo containers, making offerings, pestles and mortars, cooking fires, sacrificial offerings, pounding, and gathering for meals.
What is meant by many non-Buddhist households having multiple spheres of influence?
It means that in these households there are many different views and intentions.
What is shared and what is distinct in this influence?
It refers to the extent of the heavenly shrines.
What is meant by many non-Buddhist households having a single sphere of influence?

It means that in these households they have the same views and do not have different intentions. This influence extends throughout the house and one fathom outside, and also includes the places for drying cow dung and so forth.
What is meant by many non-Buddhist households having multiple spheres of influence?
It means that in these households there are many different views and intentions.
What is shared and what is distinct in this influence?
This does not have the force of a boundary.
How does one shop have one boundary?
It means that in this shop there is one family head whose brothers are not divided.
This boundary is the entire area in between, and one fathom outside, and also extends to the place where goods are placed, weighed, measured, and traded.
How does one shop have many boundaries?
It means that in this shop there are many family heads whose brothers are divided.ğŸ”½What is the common boundary?
What is the separate boundary?
It refers to the sitting bed for trading.
How does many shops have one boundary?
It means that in these shops there is only one family head whose brothers are not divided.
This boundary is the entire area in between, and one fathom outside, and also extends to the place where goods are placed, etc.
How does many shops have many boundaries?
It means that in these shops there are many family heads or brothers who are divided.
How far is this the boundary?
What is common?
What is separate?
This does not have the power of a field.
How does one shop have one power of a field?
It means that in this shop there is one family head whose brothers are not divided.

This power of a field is all in the middle, and outside there is one fathom. Moreover, it is the place where wheat, barley, sesame, mung beans, millet, rice, cotton, silk, and clothing are placed, weighed, measured, and traded.
How does one shop have many powers of a field?
It means that in this shop there are many shop owners or brothers who are divided.
How far is this the power of a field?
What is common?
What is separate?
It means the place where goods are placed on boards.
How does one shop have one power of a field?
It means that in these shops there is only one shop owner whose brothers are not divided.
This power of a field is all in the middle, and outside there is one fathom. Moreover, it is the place where wheat, beans, and other things are placed.
How does one shop have many powers of a field?
It means that in these shops there are many shop owners or brothers who are divided.
To what extent is this their sphere of influence?
What is common?
What is separate?
Answer:
This has no sphere of influence.
How can one building have one sphere of influence?

It means that in this building there is one building owner whose brothers are not divided. This is their sphere of influence, which is all in the middle, and extends one fathom outside. It also extends to the place where they gather to eat and drink.
How can one building have many spheres of influence?
It means that in this building there are many building owners or brothers who are divided.
To what extent is this their sphere of influence?
What is common?
What is separate?
It means the place where ladders are placed.
How can many buildings have one sphere of influence?
It means that in these buildings there is one building owner whose brothers are not divided.
This is their sphere of influence, which is all in the middle, and extends one fathom outside.
To what extent is this their sphere of influence?
What is common?
What is separate?
It refers to the place where a ladder is placed.
How is it that there are many spheres of influence for many buildings?
It refers to the case where there are many owners of those buildings, or where brothers are divided.
What is the extent of their spheres of influence?
What is common?
What is separate?
Answer:
They have no spheres of influence.
How is it that there is one sphere of influence for one field?
It refers to the case where there is one owner of that field, and brothers are not divided.
The extent of their sphere of influence is the entire middle area, with an outer area of one fathom where grain and wheat baskets are placed.
How is it that there are many spheres of influence for one field?
It refers to the case where there are many owners of that field, or where brothers are divided.
What is the extent of their spheres of influence?
What is common?
What is separate?
It refers to the boundaries of the field.
How is it that there is one sphere of influence for many fields?
It refers to the case where there is one owner of those fields, and brothers are not divided.
The range of this is the entire area in between, and one fathom outside, where grain and wheat are placed.
How can there be many ranges with many ranges?
It means that these ranges have many range owners or brothers who are divided.
To what extent is this their range?
What is common?
What is separate?
The answer:
This has no range.
How can there be one hall with one range?
It means that in this hall there is one hall owner, and the brothers are not divided.
The range of this is the entire area in between, and one fathom outside, referring to the area where cows and horses are tethered, where grass is cut and dung is discarded.
How can there be one hall with many ranges?
It means that in this hall there are many hall owners, or brothers who are divided.
To what extent is this their range?
It means reaching the inside of the gate.
How can there be many halls with one range?
It means that in these halls there is one hall owner, and the brothers are not divided.
This range is the entire area in between, and extends one fathom outside to where cows and horses are tethered, where hay is stored, and where dung is discarded.
How does a multi-hall building have multiple ranges?
It means that this multi-hall building has multiple owners of the halls, either brothers or separate individuals.
To what extent is this its range?
What is common?
What is separate?
The answer is:
This has no range.
How does a single cart have a single range?
It means that this single cart has a single owner of the cart, with no divided brothers.

This range is the entire area in between while the cart is being driven or stopped, and extends one fathom outside to where food and drink are consumed, where cows are tethered, where hay is stored, and where dung is discarded.
How does a single cart have multiple ranges?
It means that this single cart has multiple owners of the cart, either brothers or separate individuals.
To what extent is this its range?
It extends to the yoke of the cart.
What is common?
What is separate?
The common area is the place of the yoke.
How do many carts have one sphere of influence?
It means these carts have one owner, with brothers not divided.
This sphere of influence refers to the place where the carts are driven.
How do many carts have many spheres of influence?
It means these carts have many owners, or brothers divided.
To what extent is this their sphere of influence?
What is common?
What is separate?
Answer:
This has no sphere of influence.
How does one boat have one sphere of influence?
It means this one boat has one owner, with brothers not divided.
This sphere of influence refers to the entire area within the boat's movement and rest, with an area of one fathom outside for tying the boat and eating food.
How does one boat have many spheres of influence?
It means this one boat has many owners, or brothers divided.
To what extent is this their sphere of influence?
It refers to the area around the boat.
How do many boats have one sphere of influence?
It means that in these boats there is one boat owner who does not divide with his brothers.
This is the extent of their influence, referring to the movement and stopping of the boats.
How is it that many boats have many influences?
It means that in these boats there are many boat owners or brothers who divide separately.
To what extent is that their influence?
What is common?
What is separate?
Answer:
This has no influence.
How is it that one forest has one influence?
It means that in this forest there is one forest owner who does not divide with his brothers.

This is the extent of their influence, referring to the middle of this forest, all of it, and one fathom outside, and also to the place where they gather flowers and the place where they eat and drink.
How is it that one forest has many influences?
It means that this one forest has many forest owners or brothers who divide separately.
To what extent is that their influence?
It refers to the extent of the well.
How is it that many forests have one influence?
It means that in these forests there is a forest owner whose brothers do not divide.
This is the middle of the sphere of influence, outside there is one fathom, and the place where flowers are picked.
How do many forests have many spheres of influence?
It means that in these forests there are many forest owners or brothers who divide.
To what extent is this the sphere of influence?
What is common?
What is different?
Answer:
This has no sphere of influence.
How does one tree have one sphere of influence?
It means the place where the branches and leaves are intertwined, the middle is all, outside there is one fathom;

Also, at noon on the fifth day of the month, the place where the tree's shadow reaches, if there is no wind, the place where flowers, leaves, and fruits fall, and the place where raindrops reach when it rains.
How does one tree have many spheres of influence?
It means that the branches and leaves of the tree are sparse and scattered, not intertwined.
To what extent is this the sphere of influence?
What is common?
What is different?
It means this is the root of the tree.
How is it that many trees have one sphere of influence?
It means that the branches and leaves of these trees interlace, covering the area below. The space in between is all included.
How is it that many trees have multiple spheres of influence?
It means that these trees are each separate from one another, with their branches and leaves not intermingling.
To what extent is this their sphere of influence?
What is common?
What is distinct?
This has no sphere of influence.
As for bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«s, whether there is an offense or not can be understood based on the above.
At that time, the Venerable UpÄli addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One, Great Virtuous One!
If a bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä« is walking, standing, sitting, or lying down, to what extent is it within the range of the robe's sphere of influence?
The Buddha said:
Like the brahmin Åšroá¹‡aka planting an Ämalaka tree, seven fathoms apart, with luxuriant flowers and fruits.
Between these seven trees is forty-nine fathoms. Within this range, it is within the walking bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«'s robe's sphere of influence. Beyond this, it is lost.

If one is standing, sitting, or lying down, only within one fathom, or if one is lying down between two boundaries, as long as the corner of the robe does not leave the body, this is the proper range.
If a bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä« sleeps apart from her robe, she should do so for three reasons. The text on the offense is stated as before.
